user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of digest_auth_check_all:
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthResult
digest_auth_check_all (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                       const char *realm,
                       const char *username,
                       const char *password,
                       const uint8_t *userdigest,
                       unsigned int nonce_timeout,
                       uint32_t max_nc,
                       enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiQOP mqop,
                       enum MHD_DigestAuthMultiAlgo3 malgo3)
{
  enum MHD_DigestAuthResult res;
  char *buf;
  struct DigestAlgorithm da;

  buf = NULL;
  digest_setup_zero (&da);
  if (0 == nonce_timeout)
    nonce_timeout = connection->daemon->dauth_def_nonce_timeout;
  if (0 == max_nc)
    max_nc = connection->daemon->dauth_def_max_nc;
  res = digest_auth_check_all_inner (connection, realm, username, password,
                                     userdigest,
                                     nonce_timeout,
                                     max_nc, mqop, malgo3,
                                     &buf, &da);
  digest_deinit (&da);
  if (NULL != buf)
    free (buf);

  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
res = digest_auth_check_all_inner (connection, realm, username, password,
                                     userdigest,
                                     nonce_timeout,
                                     max_nc, mqop, malgo3,
                                     &buf, &da);
explanation: No direct calls to any of the <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) appear in this snippet. The other statements are simple assignments, NULL checks, calls to digest_setup_zero and digest_deinit (whose implementations are not shown here), and a free(buf) guarded by a NULL check. The only fragment that can lead to potential out-of-bounds string/memory accesses is the call to digest_auth_check_all_inner because it forwards pointers/strings (realm, username, password, userdigest, and &buf) to another function that may use the string.h functions. Therefore only that call site needs investigation; all other lines in this snippet do not themselves invoke the string handling functions and so do not need to be investigated for Rule 21.17 based on the provided code.
